thread.title: Mount Pleasant welcomes six into HOF
thread.title_full: Mount Pleasant welcomes six into HOF

author: JORDAN MOSS Tribune sports writer
title: Mount Pleasant welcomes six into HOF
text: Mount Pleasant welcomes six into HOF By JORDAN MOSS Tribune sports   This Friday night the Mount Pleasant Tigers will be honoring six individuals who have left their mark on Tigers athletics. The second Tiger Athletic Hall of Fame class will be on hand Friday night to accept their inductions during the pregame before the Tigers take on Hallsville. This years’ class features four former athletes and two former coaches. Maury Anthony Buford was a standout in three sports when he attended Mount Pleasant High School. Earning all-district honors in baseball, football and track Buford also excelled in the classroom as a member of the National Honor Society. Buford broke the school record for the 880-yard dash and was a member of the 1978 State Champions Tiger baseball team. Buford attended Texas Tech where he was named to the All-Southwest Conference team twice and had the highest national punting average as a freshman. He was drafted by the San Diego Chargers in 1982 and enjoyed a nine-year career in the NFL that included winning Super Bowl XX as a member of the legendary 1985 Chicago Bears. R. E. Dodson graduated from MPHS in 1957. A varsity member for three years on baseball, football and track Dodson racked up many accolades including: 1955 All District Football for both offense and defense; 1956 All District Football again both offense and defense; 1956 Honorable Mention All-State Football; 1955 Regional Champion in the 440-yard relay and MPHS Most Athletic 1957. Dodson had athletic scholarship offers to many schools and chose to attend Texas Christian University where was a letterman on back-to-back SWC Championship teams in 1958 and 1959. Richard Rockwell was a member of both the football and track and field teams during his time at MPHS. Rockwell was on the 1972 and 1973 Tigers football teams that won back-to-back district championships with the 73 team making it all the way to the state championship game. The 1972 track and field team won the state championship with the 1973 team finishing as the runner-up. Rockwell participated in the 1974 state meet in the 400 meters event. Leslie Slovak was another three-sport star during her time at MPHS. Slovak played basketball, volleyball and tennis. Her accolades include being named All-District and All-Region in basketball, three time All-District in volleyball, twice named All-Region and All-State in volleyball. After graduation Slovak attended East Texas State University, now known as Texas A&M Commerce, where she played volleyball. Slovak was named t0 All-Conference three times, a four-time Lone Star Conference Player of the Week, set the NCAA record for all division I, II and III schools for most kills in a match. She is third on the all-time kill list at A&M Commerce and third on the all-time list for most aces. There isn’t much that Charles Wright didn’t do during his time working at Mount Pleasant ISD. In his 37 years working for the school district Wright worked as a teacher, counselor, teacher evaluator, assistant superintendent and superintendent. His coaching career included coaching eighth grade in all sports at P.E. Wallace, ninth grade in football and track, being a varsity assistant football coach working with the defense and head track and field coach at Mount Pleasant High School. As a student at MPHS Wright was named captain of the football team his senior year and was selected to multiple all-tournament teams in basketball. In 1955 Herb Zimmerman was tasked with turning Tigers football around. The man from Mount Vernon did just that taking Mount Pleasant all the way to the state semi-finals in 1959. Zimmerman grew up in Mount Vernon and played college football at TCU. In his senior year in 1952 Zimmerman was named to the All-Southwest Conference team and was an honorable mention All-American. Zimmerman was drafted by the Green Bay Packers but an injury prevented him from joining the team. After the 1959 season Zimmerman joined the coaching staff of John Bridgers at Baylor University as a defensive coach and later defensive coordinator. In 1966 legendary coach Hayden Fry hired Zimmerman to come to Southern Methodist University to be the defensive coordinator. TCU honored Zimmerman in 1995 with an induction into the TCU Sports Hall of Fame. Tiger fans are encouraged to attend the reception for the HOF class at 5 p.m. this Friday in the administration building. There will be a meet and greet where fans can talk to the class and their families. The induction of the class will take place during the pregame festivities for the Hallsville game beginning at 6:45 p.m. at Sam Parker Field.
